page.title: 07The Village of Weston
page.content:
Weston-on-the-Green existed long before the original Domesday Survey was undertaken. The{name}is Saxon in origin and means village or homestead to the west. Parts of the village green can still be seen: an old pair of stocks gives some indication how the green was used in former times.
Despite its position on the A43, Weston is a pretty village, built mainly of Cotswold Stone. Properties, gardens and public amenities are well kept. Many{old houses}retain their {thatched roofs,}though most have been extended indicating the modern need for improved accommodation, garages, etc. Most{new houses}have been built in reconstituted stone which blends well with local stone. An exception is a group of{council houses}which seem grey and rectangular in comparison.
